posts.name: JAMES
posts.cooked:
The user provided a piece of text that needs cleaning up. They mentioned removing all HTML tags and unnecessary elements while preserving the original meaning using proper English grammar and punctuation. The output should be a single paragraph without line breaks.

First sentence: "get rotated idiot climb" – this seems to be a random phrase or maybe a typo. There's no context given, so it might be challenging to interpret correctly. However, considering the instruction to remove HTML tags, I'll proceed accordingly.

Second sentence contains an anchor tag with class "mention" and href. The text inside the tag is "@Japple”’s patent pending design." After removing the tag, it becomes "@Japple’s patent-pending design."

Putting both sentences together without any additional words or formatting, the result is: "get rotated idiot climb @Japple’s patent-pending design." 

I considered whether there are other unnecessary elements besides HTML tags, but since the instruction focuses primarily on removing tags, I kept the rest as is. If more context were available, further adjustments could have been made for clarity. Overall, minimal changes were made to comply with the instructions.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: The Holy Cows also do it; their climb sequence is both dramatic and fast, flipping sideways.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: Here are some past upside down climbs I found on YouTube

posts.name: Jared
posts.cooked: Extremely tough climb. Started with understanding the background, historical performance, and evolution of the robot team. Discussed various aspects including coral placement, motor changes, structural modifications, and gear ratios. Explored different approaches to the deep climb, emphasizing the balance between aesthetics and functionality. Mentioned challenges like weight distribution and elevator mechanics. Discussed design iterations, including the bellypan approach, and highlighted the importance of adaptability based on team constraints. Highlighted the trade-offs between unique designs and practicality, ultimately deciding on the final approach for the season.

posts.name: Jared
posts.cooked: Here’s a link to our CAD: Onshape. KrayonCAD is in another document, but all the 2D sketches, which are key parts of the design process, are located in the "Robot Sketches" section. Feel free to check them out to see how our robot developed over the course of the season.
